facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1789 to 1791 of 1969 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1789 to 1791 of 1969. Appeals by special leave from the judgments

facts.text: Appeals from judgments and orders dated June 11, 1969, and July 10, 1969 of the Kerala High Court in Writ Appeals Nos. 126 of 1968 and 762 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgments and orders dated June 11, 1969, and July 10, 1969 of the Kerala High Court in Writ Appeals Nos. 126 of 1968 and 762 of 1969.

facts.text: Kerala High Court division bench affirmed the decision of a learned single judge who dismissed the writ petitions of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: ment of a division bench of the Kerala High Court.-affirming the decision of a learned single judge who had dismissed the writ ,petitions of the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. 1789/69 entered service as a teacher in a private aided school on March 14, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in C.A. 1789/69 entered service as a teacher in a private aided school on March 14, 1946.

facts.text: Both appellants in C.A. 1790/69 entered government school service on August 17, 1958 and December 13, 1948 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellants in C.A. 1790/69 had joined service originally as teachers in aided schools but they entered government school service on August 17, 1958 and December 13, 1948 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. 1791/69 joined government service as a teacher and attained the age of 55 on July 2, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in C.A. 1791/69 the appellant joined government service as a teacher and attained the age of 55 on July 2, 1968.

facts.text: On November 22, 1965 all associations of government and private aided school teachers submitted a memorandum to the government demanding raise of retirement age to 60 years.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on November 22, 1965 all associations of government and private aided school teachers of which the appellants were members submitted a memorandum to the government making various demands. One of these  No. 11  was that the age of retirement of school teachers should be raised to 60 years.

facts.text: On July 14, 1966 the government issued an order raising the age of retirement from 55 to 58 years effective from 1-7-1966.

anchor.surface_text: On July 14, 1966 the government issued an order by which the age of retirement was raised from 55 to 58 years. Paragraph 8 of this order was in the following terms- The age of retirement of all teachers including Head Masters of aided schools will be raised to 58 with effect from 1-7-1966.

facts.text: The order of July 14, 1966 allowed appointing authority to require teacher to retire after 55 with approval and three months notice.

anchor.surface_text: This will be subject to the companydition that the appointing authority may with previous approval of the Director of Public Instruction in the case of High and Training Schools require the teacher to retire after he attains the age of 55 years, on three months numberice without assigning any reason.

facts.text: On May 4, 1967 government issued order lowering age of compulsory retirement to 55 years in supersession of previous orders.

anchor.surface_text: On May 4, 1967 another order was issued by the government in supersession of the previous orders. By this order the age of companypulsory retirement of all government employees and aided school teachers whose age of retirement on superannuation under the existing order was 58 years was lowered to 55 years.

facts.text: May 4, 1967 order stated those who crossed 55 or attain within three months retire after three months expiry.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, stated that all those who had already crossed the age of 55 years or who might attain the age of 55 within a period of three months from the date of the order would retire only on the date of expiry of three months.

facts.text: Amendments made to Kerala Education Rules under Act 6 of 1959 and Kerala Service Rules under Article 309.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary amendments were formally made both in the Kerala Education Rules framed under the Act 6 of 1959 and the Kerala Service Rules made by the Governor in exercise of the powers companyferred by the proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Kerala Education Act, 1958 (Act 6 of 1959) enacted for better organisation of educational institutions.

anchor.surface_text: Act 6 of 1959 was enacted to provide for the better Organisation and development of educational institutions in the State.

facts.text: Section 12(1) of Act 6 of 1959 provides conditions of service including age of retirement prescribed by government.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 1  of the Act provides that the companyditions of service of teachers in aided schools including the companyditions relating to pay, pension, provident fund, insurance and age of retirement shall be such as may be prescribed by the government.

facts.text: Rule 8 in Chapter XXVII-A of Kerala Education Rules: age of retirement on superannuation 55 years.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8 in Chapter XXVII-A appearing under the head pension is in the following terms- The age of retirement on superannuation shall be 55 years.

facts.text: Note to Rule 8: those in service prior to 4-9-1957 age of retirement 60 years, service beyond 55 not qualify for pension.

anchor.surface_text: Note.-In the case of those who were in service of any aided school prior to 4-9-1957 the age of retirement on superannuation shall be 60 years subject to the companydition that the service beyond 55 years shall number qualify for pension and gratuity under these rules.

facts.text: Chapter XXVII-B rules came into force on 1-10-1964 and apply to certain aided school teachers.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules in this Chapter shall companye into force on 1-10-1964. These Rules shall apply to teachers in aided schools to whom the rules in Chapter XIV C  Kerala Education Rules apply.

facts.text: Rule 4 Chapter XXVII-B: date of compulsory retirement for aided school teachers same as government school teachers.

anchor.surface_text: The date of companypulsory retirement on superannuation applicable to teachers of government schools shall apply to teachers of aided schools.

facts.text: Appellant in C.A. 1789/69 exercised the option under Rule 2 Chapter XXVII-B read with Rule 4.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the appellant in C.A. 1789/69 exercised the option in terms of the above rules. Thus by virtue of Rule 2 in Chapter XXVII B  read with Rule 4 the date of his companypulsory retirement on superannuation would be the same as was applicable to teachers of government schools.

facts.text: Petitioner in CA 1789/69 claimed entitled to Rule 8 Chapter XXVII-A benefit of 60 years retirement as pre-1957 service.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed on his behalf that the provisions of Chapters XXVII-A and B were number mutually exclusive and be was entitled to the benefit of Rule 8 in Chapter XXVII-A. As he was in service of an aided school prior to September 4, 1957 his age of retirement of superannuation was to be 60 years.

facts.text: Court held Chapters XXVII-A and XXVII-B mutually exclusive; appellant in 1789/69 retirement age 55 like government teachers.

anchor.surface_text: The approach of the division bench was that the provisions of Chanter XXVIIA and XXVIIB when read together leave numberdoubt that the two chapters are mutually exclusive. ... The age of companypulsory retirement for the latter class of teachers was 55 and it followed that that would be the age of superannuation for the aforesaid appellant.

facts.text: Petitioners claimed government orders resulted in binding agreement or contract from which government cannot resile.

anchor.surface_text: Another point which has been strenuous urged is that the government orders which followed the memorandum submitted by the teachers were the result of an understanding which companyld well. be regarded, as a binding agreement or companytract between the government and the teachers from which it was number open to the government to resile unilaterally.

facts.text: Court rejected claim of binding agreement; power under Art. 309 and s.12 Act 6/1959 not fettered by agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The first limb of this argument was disposed of by the learned single judge by rightly pointing out that the power of the government under Art. 309 of the Constitution to make rules regulating the companyditions of service of government employees or of teachers in aided schools under s. 12 of Act 6 of 1959 companyld in numberway be fettered by any agreement even if such an agreement was proved.

facts.text: Petitioners invoked estoppel based on government representations, court rejected as no representation acted upon to detriment.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of estoppel can hardly be invoked in the circumstances of the case although support was sought from certain decisions of this Court. ... These principles can hardly be applied here because there is numberquestion of any representation having been made by the government which was acted upon to their detriment by the appellants.

facts.text: Exhibit P-6: proceedings of District Education Officer, Kottayam mentioning order dated March 10, 1967 raising age to 58.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit P-6 is a companyy of proceedings of the District Education Officer, Kottayam. It companytains a mention of order dated March 10, 1967 in which it is stated that the age of companypulsory retirement of all officers in the State had been raised to 58 as per the  1  1968 2 S. C. R. 366. government orders mentioned therein.

facts.text: Exhibit P-7: proceedings of District Educational Officer, Palghat listing teachers to continue beyond 55.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly exhibit P.7 is a companyy of the proceedings of the District Educational Officer, Palghat, in which the names of teachers who were to companytinue beyond the age of 55 was given.

facts.text: Court held change in retirement rule valid, does not attract Art. 311 or 14.

anchor.surface_text: Change in the rule relating to retirement can be validly made and it does number attract either Art. 311 2  or Art. 14 of the Constitution see Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh Others 1 .

facts.text: Petitioners relied on Rules 5 and 6 of Kerala Service Rules claiming reduction from 58 to 55 disadvantageous without consent.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance has also been placed on behalf of the appellants on Rules 5 and 6 of the Kerala Service Rules. ... The point sought to be made is that once the age of retirement was raised to 58 it companyld number be reduced to 55 owing to the provisions of these Rules.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Chapters XXVII-A and XXVII-B are mutually exclusive and whether the appellant in C.A. 1789/69, having exercised the option under Chapter XXVII-B read with Chapter XIV-C, is entitled to the benefit of Rule 8 (including the Note) in Chapter XXVII-A for retirement at 60 years?

anchor.surface_text: We may first deal with the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant in the above appeal. It was claimed on his behalf that the provisions of Chapters XXVII-A and B were not mutually exclusive and he was entitled to the benefit of Rule 8 in Chapter XXVII-A. As he was in service of an aided school prior to September 4, 1957 his age of retirement of superannuation was to be 60 years. The approach of the division bench was that the provisions of Chanter XXVIIA and XXVIIB when read together leave no doubt that the two chapters are mutually exclusive.

issues.text: Whether the government orders following the teachers' memorandum constituted a binding agreement or contract from which the government could not unilaterally resile, or whether the rule of estoppel applies to prevent reduction of retirement age?

anchor.surface_text: Another point which has been strenuously urged is that the government orders which followed the memorandum submitted by the teachers were the result of an understanding which could well be regarded, as a binding agreement or contract between the government and the teachers from which it was number open to the government to resile unilaterally. Alternatively a rule similar to that of estoppel could be invoked.

issues.text: Whether the change in retirement age from 58 back to 55 years is valid and does not violate Articles 311(2) or 14 of the Constitution, particularly in light of Exhibits P-6 and P-7?

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has also been invited, particularly on behalf of the appellants in C.As. 1790 and 1791, to exhibits P-6 and P-7. ... Change in the rule relating to retirement can be validly made and it does number attract either Art. 311 2  or Art. 14 of the Constitution see Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh Others 1 .

issues.text: Whether Rules 5 and 6 of the Kerala Service Rules prevent the reduction of retirement age from 58 to 55 years without the consent of the teachers?

anchor.surface_text: Reliance has also been placed on behalf of the appellants on Rules 5 and 6 of the Kerala Service Rules. According to Rule 5 numberhing in the Rules or in any Rule made thereunder shall operate to deprive any person of any right or privilege to which he is entitled by or under any law or by the terms of any companytract or agreement Subsisting between such person and government on the date the Rules came into force.

As he was in service of an aided school prior to September 4, 1957 his age of retirement of superannuation was to be 60 years.

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions when read together leave no doubt mutually exclusive; Chapter XXVII-B independent and inconsistent with XXVII-A; Rule 4 makes retirement age same as government teachers at 55; Rule 2(a) Ch XIV-C confirms 55; concur with High Court

arguments.claim: Provisions of Chapters XXVII-A and XXVII-B when read together leave no doubt that the two chapters are mutually exclusive

anchor.surface_text: The approach of the division bench was that the provisions of Chanter XXVIIA and XXVIIB when read together leave no doubt that the two chapters are mutually exclusive. Chapter XXVIIB makes independent and separate provisions which are inconsistent with those contained in Chapter XXVIIA.

The age of compulsory retirement for the latter class of teachers was 55 and it followed that that would be the age of superannuation for the aforesaid appellant.

arguments.claim: Teachers under Chapter XIV-C retire at age of 55

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed also on Rule 2 a  of Chapter XIV C  which expressly states that teachers who come under the provisions of Chapter XIV C  shall retire at the age of 55.

holdings.text: The provisions of Chapters XXVII-A and XXVII-B of the Kerala Education Rules are mutually exclusive and the appellant in C.A. 1789/69 cannot claim the benefit of Rule 8 of Chapter XXVII-A for retirement at 60 years, but is subject to retirement at 55 years as applicable to government school teachers.

anchor.surface_text: The approach of the division bench was that the provisions of Chanter XXVIIA and XXVIIB when read together leave no doubt that the two chapters are mutually exclusive. Chapter XXVIIB makes independent and separate provisions which are inconsistent with those contained in Chapter XXVIIA.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of rules shows mutual exclusivity; option under Rule 2 Chapter XXVII-B read with Rule 4 aligns aided school teacher with government school retirement age of 55; concurrence with High Court view.

holdings.text: The power of the government under Article 309 of the Constitution and Section 12 of Act 6 of 1959 cannot be fettered by any agreement or contract, and no such contract can be spelt out from the memorandum and government orders.

anchor.surface_text: the power of the government under Art. 309 of the Constitution to make rules regulating the conditions of service of government employees or of teachers in aided schools under s. 12 of Act 6 of 1959 could in no way be fettered by any agreement even if such an agreement was proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory powers to regulate service conditions override any alleged agreement; no authority supports inferring contract from documents.

holdings.text: The rule of estoppel does not apply as there was no representation by the government acted upon to the detriment of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The rule of estoppel can hardly be invoked in the circumstances of the case although support was sought from certain decisions of this Court. ... These principles can hardly be applied here because there is no question of any representation having been made by the government which was acted upon to their detriment by the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No detrimental reliance on any government representation; distinguished from Indo-Afghan Agencies case; service conditions changeable under constitutional and statutory powers.

holdings.text: Change in the rule relating to age of retirement is valid and does not attract Article 311(2) or Article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Change in the rule relating to retirement can be validly made and it does not attract either Art. 311 2  or Art. 14 of the Constitution see Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh Others 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Bishun Narain Mishra; Exhibits P-6 and P-7 do not alter validity of subsequent order reducing age to 55.

precedents.citation: Union of India Ors. v. M s.Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd.,  1

anchor.surface_text: Union of India Ors. v. M s.Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd.,  1  this Court held that where a person had acted upon the representation made in the export promotion scheme that import licence upto the value of the goods exported would be issued and had actually exported goods his claim for an import licence for the maximum value permissible by the scheme could not be arbitrarily rejected. It was observed that the claim in that case was founded upon the equity which arose as a result of representation made on behalf of the government in the export promotion scheme and the action taken by the respondents there acting upon the representation.

precedents.case_name: Union of India & Ors. v. M/s Indo-Afghan Agencies Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Promissory estoppel applies against government where a person acts upon its representation in an export promotion scheme to their detriment
precedents.cited_holding: where a person had acted upon the representation made in the export promotion scheme that import licence upto the value of the goods exported would be issued and had actually exported goods his claim for an import licence for the maximum value permissible by the scheme could not be arbitrarily rejected

precedents.citation: Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Constitution see Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh Others 1 . Reliance has also been placed on behalf of the appellants on Rules 5 and 6 of the Kerala Service Rules.

precedents.case_name: Bishun Narain Mishra v. State of Uttar Pradesh & Others
precedents.cited_proposition: Change in the rule relating to retirement can be validly made and it does not attract either Art. 311 or Art. 14 of the Constitution

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants' contentions rejected; retirement age fixed at 55 years as per government school teachers; no benefit of higher age from other rules or estoppel
